dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Stygean darkness. Wet CLICKING SOUNDS. A BEAM of purplish ULTRA-VIOLET LIGH reveals a mosaic of moving forms... COCKROACHES. They ski restlessly under the beam's intensity. SERIES OF SHOTS -- UV Beam passing over various parts of the space. Pipe web walls, girders -- all covered with the insects. Thousands them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Innards of steel. A vast maze of tunnels. A GROUP OF FIGURES advances through the tunnels with hand UV lamps. The figures are dressed in gray air-tight NEOPRENE SUITS, their faces hidden by skin tight MASKS and bug-like NIGHT VISION GOGGLES. In the dense silence, respirator valves H CLICK at the corner of their lips in mechanical rhythm. The scene has a dream-like, choreographed quality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eerie, aquatic green.  The horde of insects appear to be kind of sea-life, crawling over the floor of a dead ocean

dialogues.speaker: THE TEAM OF FIGURES
dialogues.text: From their midst appears another FIGURE, its neoprene sui flat WHITE.  Female, clearly the TEAM LEADER. She carries a stainless steel CONTAINER filled with twent small compartments, each bearing a large, heavy-shelled r with a different BARCODE on their back. JUDAS ROACHES. She kneels and opens the

dialogues.speaker: CASE
dialogues.text: TCHK!! A dozen of the Judas roaches are released.  They s through into the area.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEARBY ROACHES
dialogues.text: react instantaneously.  In a rustle of tiny legs, they be to stream toward the Judases. Jostle and fight each other for position to mate with the They even crawl over the Team Leader in an effort to reac the Judases.  The Team Leader makes no effort to brush th off.  Patient, almost godlike, she watches the MATING.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: A MANHOLE has been opened above. CHAINS are dropped down attached by a Team Member to A 100-GALLON DISPOSAL DRUM. REVEAL the floor of the tunnel, carpeted with the still f of the roaches, now all DEAD. The Team Members quietly shovel the tiny corpses into oth disposal drums. At their feet skitter the only survivors of the massacre: the bar-coded Judas Roaches. In a crunch of machinery, the first disposal drum is lift by the chains through the manhole to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIDTOWN MANHATTAN.  A cacophony of SOUND and LIGHT. Dirty snow drifts over Bryant Park. Emergency lights blin everywhere. A wall of cars sits on Sixth Avenue, stopped dead. Exhaust fumes hang in the air. Jaded TRAFFIC COPS s the cars on crosstown detours. Mounted policemen patrol a line of yellow sawhorses near dozens of Department of Public Health vehicles, angle-par in a military phalanx. A monumental ribcage-like scaffolding has been erected in middle of the street, "sealing" the area with amber plast Inside, UNIFORMED WORKERS take the disposal drum of roach and toss it into one of a number of huge DUMPSTERS. The Team Leader watches from nearby, exhauster.  Her mask off. We see her face: Enthomologist SUSAN WYETH, 28. An ARM gently drapes over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we doing? She looks over at DR. PETER TYLER, 34, bespectacled.  A HEADSET around his neck, a coat emblazoned with the DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH logo.  He has the look of a man who' just fought a long battle and come out victorious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see... He offers her a bite of a PAY DAY CANDYBAR.  Susan smiles shakes her head.  She wearily leans against him. Peter looks out as the dumpster filled with roaches is ra by MECHANICAL ARMS into the waiting maw of the dump truck THE SCREEN. DARKNESS. A voice, a somber bas-relief in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strickler's Disease crept into Manhattan like a thief in the night, claiming its first hundred victims before it was even classified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FLOAT through a long hospital ward. Past ROWS of illuminated oxygen tents, pulsating softly i the dark like cocoons of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most were children under ten. TRACK past tents.  BODIES OF SMALL CHILDREN inside, wrapp in white sheets, hooked up to IVs or breathing apparatus. Skeletal hands, parched lips, glazed eyes. BELLOWS of respirators push in and out, labored, failing. IMAGE RESOLVES TO A VIDEO ON A SCREEN. PULL BACK to reveal a number of SCREENS, each with a different set of images.  We are in a NEWS VAN.   A TECHNICIAN and DIRECTOR sit watching. The voice belongs to an ANCHORMAN who's now overimposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only after the numbers had reached into the thousands were officials able to identify the carrier of the deadly infection...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut to three. The Technician manipulates the controls.  On another scre we see them cut to STOCK NEWS FOOTAGE: regular cockroache crawling on garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blattida Germanica.  The common cockroach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To a RUNNER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them we're ready for a live feed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The runner exits the News Van.  Other such vehicles parke nearby.  A CROWD of ONLOOKERS, REPORTERS and a gaggle of PROTESTERS with handpainted signs. Gliding past them, we pick up sound bites...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an insect that has proven virtually immune to chemical control...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the announcement by the Health Department that an end to the nightmare has finally... REPORTER 3 is interviewing a Greenpeace PROTESTER who is holding up a photograph of Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an ex-colleague of Doctor Susan Wyeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Susan has always been opposed to biological tampering. A real advocate for ecological causes, it's not... MOVE past them to further inside of the perimeter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NEWS CONFERENCE in progress.  A packed house.  T.V. monitors spaced ever 10 seats or so. In the audience, the MAYOR OF NEW YORK and various CITY OFFICIALS, listening t Peter, speaking at the podium with the ease and enthusias a public servant still untainted by bureaucracy.

dialogues.speaker: ON A TV MONITOR
dialogues.text: While Peter talks, a news title appears at the bottom of screen: PETER TYLER. DEPUTY DIRECTOR, DEPARTMENT OF HEALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrapping up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...in Nature, evolution is a long, leisurely conversation between an organism and its environment. We, however, did not have the luxury of time... Susan is waiting in the wings. She observes the audience. She notices that the entire front row is composed of CHIL who have survived Strickler's.  Leg and arm braces, facia scarring... He nods at Susan, who takes the podium, adjusting her jac slightly ill at ease in her business suit.  She clears he throat, speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the aid of genetic labs throughout the country, we recombined cockroach DNA with genetic information from termites and mantids. We were able to create a biological counter-agent.  A new ally, if you will... She places a clear container on the podium for all to see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blattida Traditor.

dialogues.speaker: CU CONTAINER
dialogues.text: One of the Judas roaches skitters about in the container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Judas Roach". Cameras FLASH.  MURMURS from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judas is a non-carrier of Stricklers, with a short life-span and heightened pheromone emission. On the back row she can see some ecological hand-painted signs being raised in silent protest. She stumbles for a second, then resumes her speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The female is basically a sexual magnet; common males travelled miles and fought for the right to mate with them. The audience is rapt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they did, they took away something else we added -- a hormone, passed through sexual congress that causes their metabolism to go into overdrive.  No matter what their food intake, they starved to death in a matter of hours. Now Peter takes the mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've achieved almost total eradication of the roach population.  As of today, the disease has been officially contained. A STANDING OVATION starts and is carried on as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a tub in a dark bathroom. Her business suit crumpled on the bathroom floor.  SOUND of a TV outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sus, come on.  You're missing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing grand.  Peter in his shorts at a TV with shitty reception.  He adjusts the disgruntled cable box. He is seen over the TV, giving his address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking thing! I hope someone's taping this. (Out.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, come on.  It's really good this time. I got most of the lines out. (No response.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sus? Peter sighs. He picks up an open bottle of champagne and two mis-matched ceramic cups, then heads for the bathroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life's a bitch. Our 15 minutes came and went and all we got was bad cable... Susan doesn't answer, clearly not in the same high spirit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiding from the hard glare of publicity? He notices her crumpled garment on the floor.  He picks i up, puts it up on the hanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shame.  You looked great tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did! He sits by the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we did the right thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking a cab instead of hiring a limo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean... Peter pours some champagne into the cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did no impact evaluation.  The consequences of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a Catholic guilt thing...? We hear a NEWSREADER on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a flawless strategy which has stopped a potential epidemic in its tracks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear that?  Flawless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just don't know. He offers one cup to Susan.  She doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know we saved lives. He sits closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There're gonna be a lot of kids running around next year because of you. Beat.  Susan starts to relax. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who know?  We get lucky, maybe a couple of 'em'll be ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're down to a "couple" now, huh? She pats the water, beckoning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. People are beginning to talk about us... Still partially clothed, he steps into the bathtub. Susan shakes her head, laughs ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll save your honor. Maybe I'll even marry you. She reaches over, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE dimly visible through the rain.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHABET CITY STREETS
dialogues.text: Empty warehouses. Closed businesses. Traffic lights blink on empty streets. Everything seems doomed under the heavy layer of rain.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: A DILAPIDATED BUILDING before us. A blazing NEON CROSS ma of the words 'JESUS SAVES' hangs askew from its facade. CRANE to see the ROOFTOP. WHAM! The door to the interior stairs FLIES OPEN and a ta thin CHINESE PREACHER in his sixties lurches out, eyes wi with terror. He looks back down the steps. Something's climbing up fast, casting ominous, complex shadows on the wall. Too many FOOTSTEPS for it to be just one person. The man hurriedly shuts the door and slides a bolt home. Trembling, he backs away as a booming THUD makes the door shudder. Raw, frenzied pounding and scratching follows... something inhuman, determined to break through. The metal surface suddenly buckles and bulges. On the man's white undershirt, a blotch of blood starts t grow.  Needles of rain stab his flesh. He searches wildly for a possible escape. He reaches the edge of the roof: it's five floors down to sidewalk. Two of the hinges on the door come loose, pulverizing the surrounding concrete. WHAM!  The door to the stairs bulges outward as something SMASHES against it again and again.  Frenzied SCRATCHING. The man sprints to the other end of the roof. There, on t adjoining building...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one floor below on the building across the alley is suspended PAINTERS' PLATFORM, crowded with paint cans und tarp.  A two-story old EYEWEAR ADVERTISEMENT from the 40' being painted over.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHINESE PREACHER
dialogues.text: Looks back to the door.  BAM! a tremendous SHATTERING sou LIGHT spills from inside. Two bolts fly in the air, a hin gives. He CRIES OUT in terror. The man gauges the distance between buildings; can he mak it? He takes a few steps back, a few more... Panting hard, he closes his eyes, his chest soaked in blo and rain.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR EXPLODES OUTWARD AND SKIDS ACROSS THE SLIPPERY R
dialogues.text: Light from inside projects the shadow of wild, busy thing onto the curtain of rain. Weeping with fear, the man desperately tries to hurl hims to the catwalk. It's too far. He FALLS...CRASH!  he hits the platform, knocking boards loose and sending paint cans onto their sides, rolling. bounces, slides off the edge, barely able to grab onto a loose board to save himself from falling. The RAIN blasts down.  The scaffold CREAKS.  He hits the edge, upsetting the cans of paint there. He holds onto the planks with all his might, trying to pu with his feet, but they slide on the wet wall.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW
dialogues.text: Cans bounce off the pavement. White pain blasts all over.

dialogues.speaker: CU HANDS
dialogues.text: The man's hands slip on the planks, tiring.

dialogues.speaker: FEET
dialogues.text: The Chinese Preacher's FEET bicycle in the air, unable to find a purchase on the wet brick wall-

dialogues.speaker: THE CHINESE PREACHER
dialogues.text: is hanging just in front of the painted EYE of the fortie model.  He looks up above him, sees something-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Please, God, no! A SHADOW crosses his face as something looms above him. Suddenly there is a CRACK and the platform tilts complete on one end.

dialogues.speaker: HANDS
dialogues.text: The Chinese Preacher's fingernails dig in, then slip on t wet wood. His hands paw the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment his body, silhouetted in the rain, seems suspended in a void. Then he falls backwards.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUND
dialogues.text: Impact. His body cracks the pavement. Small pools of rain form on his dead, open eyes. We CRANE to reveal

dialogues.speaker: A WINDOW ON A BUILDING ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: CHUY, a young Latino boy. He stares out the window at the Chinese Preacher's body with no discernable emotion. He works a small WIRE SCULPTURE in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT
dialogues.text: It's a small one-bedroom apartment. An old man sleeps peacefully on a cot: Chuy's grandfather MANNY GAVIOLA, mid 60's, white hair haloes his handsome, benign face. All around him: SHOES, shoes everywhere you look, on the table, on the chairs, on the kitchen counter, on the floo A small altar is illuminated by votive candles. Next to i standing by the window is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a blurry vision of The Chinese Preacher's splayed figure in a swirl of color. Chuy's attention focuses on the Preacher's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxfords, 8 1/2. Black... He looks away from the body and goes back to twisting the wire into shape.

dialogues.speaker: THE PUDDLE OF PAINT
dialogues.text: around the preacher, reflects large shadows moving above, and across the neon sign...

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: hears a strange sound, a rhythmic clicking. His head lifts and what he sees causes his expression to change--there is an uncharacteristic flicker of excitemen his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE ROOFTOP
dialogues.text: We are behind whatever it is that has captured Chuy's attention. TICKETY-TACKETY-TOCK... The strange clicking sound grows louder.  The figure begi moving in some weird, preparatory fashion. Then it steps forward and drops out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: His eyes follow the figure down to the pavement in a slow arc. Chuy puts down the wire miniature and opens the window to a better view.

dialogues.speaker: GROUND LEVEL
dialogues.text: The Chinese Preacher's body is now being dragged toward t rear of the alley, leaving colored paint smears in its wa

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: We isolate the boy's face and, on the soundtrack, every o noise FADES AWAY. Chuy reaches for a pair of SPOONS nearby. He begins to click them together. Imitating the strange clicking sound heard a moment ago.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHINESE PREACHER
dialogues.text: is being pulled into a small, ground-level vent. The only problem is that no human is small enough to squeeze throu this hole.

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: watches, still clicking with his spoons.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHINESE PREACHER'S BODY
dialogues.text: is stuck. One of his legs is through the hole up to the thigh, but the other is folded up unnaturally and pressin against the wall next to the vent. Impossible. There is a silent beat, and then a series of INCREDIBLY VIOLENT TUGS, BAM! BAM! BAM! shaking the Paint-soaked bod like a rag doll.

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: His spoons stop. His jaw tightens a little as we hear terrible cracking and scraping sounds.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: The Chinese Preacher's head and hands disappear into the hole. Bits of clothing, paint and blood stick to the edge the opening.

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: watches, still fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, funny shoes... He starts a new wire sculpture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is covered in sweat, running at a good clip around Central Park reservoir. A beautiful day dawns behind him; windows of the Beresford sparkle in the morning sun. Peter outperforms most of the other RUNNERS in the track, steady rhythm evidence of years of practice. Keeping his stride, he runs off the track and past a flock of OLD NUN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, ladies... Without slowing down, Peter retakes the path and moves pa them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter finally slows down. He checks his pulse and stops a water fountain. As he drinks, he sees a DERELICT drawing a figure on the sidewalk. The derelict spots Peter.  He picks up his chalk, drifts Intrigued, Peter goes closer to the drawing. An arrow poi to a manhole cover set among the bushes. Peter circles around, trying to make sense out of the lin Then the painted motif finally reveals itself.

dialogues.speaker: GRAFFITI
dialogues.text: A talismanic figure of raw, archetypal power. A few jagge lines form the shape of a MAN IN AN OVERCOAT. His face is little more than a malignant blotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room of half-finished exhibits. A group of SCULPTORS -- most of them undergraduates -- work on a gigantic piece representing a termite mound.  They're supervised by SIRI punkish young Indian research assistant. Susan talks to some of the sculptors about a 100-1 scale clay model of an insect's head.  She gestures to the model's mandible set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...no, guys, these have to fit perfectly.  No spaces in between. Let me tell you why. Insects have no hands. All they have is this set of mandibles. She grabs the outer mandible set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  This little piggy will grab the prey. Then unfolds a second set...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then this little piggy will tear it in half... And a third!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and this little one will grind it to a pulp and push it in... all the way into the mouth.  These are precision tools here. Can you remember that? The guys nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Then get it right. A piece of the termite mound is raised above their heads, revealing... ...Peter, at the entrance, still dressed in his jogging sweats. He smiles at Susan.

dialogues.speaker: EXHIBITS
dialogues.text: Peter and Susan walk through.  Peter pulls something from KNAPSACK.  A bottle of medicine marked: METALLININ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Baby in a bottle..." He gives it to Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tease. Around them, WORKMEN begin unloading crates of display st as a MAN on a ladder tacks up an "ARCHITECTS OF NATURE" banner. Susan proceeds behind an exhibit representing a honeycomb.  Peter follows as she begins to arrange some t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where they get this fertility stuff?  They extract it from the urine of menopausal Italian nuns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monks bottle their own wine. Don't they? She gently touches her belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me. I've never been this late. Never. She shakes the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If nun's pee is what it takes... Peter's cellular RINGS from his knapsack. Susan grabs a larvae model from a pile on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the one who ran around with ice in his underwear, don't forget that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get kinky here... Peter takes the call. Susan cuts away the excess plastic the lid around the honeycomb moldings. The larvae fits perfectly inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, meet me out front. (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go. Josh's picking me up in five. see you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be late. He kisses her and leaves. Susan turns to Siri and the gro working on that sculpture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siri, sandblast that thing. It looks like Trump Tower.  Those mounds are supposed to be made of dirt and excretions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wicked smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like Trump Tower, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Department of Health VAN honks its way through a traffi jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's right hand man, JOSH MASLOW -- a young, good-natu can-do guy -- drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So I say "buddy, you have every violation in the book.  Gimme one good reason not to close you down." You know what the Kraut says to me? In the back, Peter finishes changing out of his jogging sweats and into his worksuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blintzes!  "Try the blintzes..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distractedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Selling your sould for a fistful of carbohydrates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just any carbohydrates, mind you. It was like being on the receiving end of some kind of transcendent oral sex. (honks furiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should get a strobe on this thing. Maybe even a siren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and a loudspeaker so you can yell "Epidemic! Epidemic! You're all going to die!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Department of Health van pulls up outside the flophou where the Chinese Preacher died. Peter and Josh get out. COPS push back a few ONLOOKERS. Josh proudly flashes his badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Health Department... The cops let them pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really love flashing that thing, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I'm a short guy. Waddaya want? Two cops -- WOYCHEK and RICE -- approach, in no real hurr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Tyler, DOH. You gentlemen were the first on the scene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures to Rice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were both on patrol, saw this paint mess. Then I looked through that cellar window. We both did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gone in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We waited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Peter peeks through a narrow cellar window on the floor. Through the oily, smeared window, a ghostly array of PALE FACE AND HANDS appears, startling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Josh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the EMT's in there, now.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: PARAMEDIC AMBULANCES rush in. Sirens at full blast. Stepping out of the building across, Manny walks next to Chuy, who holds his hand. The old man carries a box full shoes. Chuy looks back at the cop circus, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Chuy, we're gonna be late. (discreetly crossing himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops are bad news. Don't look at them. He gently pulls his grandson's hand and moves briskly awa

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: uses an iron bar, and breaks a padlocked cellar door. A h stench emanates from inside. The cops cover their noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Josh enter a dingy, dungeon-like cellar, illuminated only by bug zappers and emergency lights. Eve door and window has been nailed shut or sports a heavy-du padlock. Peter and Josh walk through the dismal scene. In sharp contrast with the dirt-smeared walls, we see shi metallic SEWING MACHINES and swatches of cloth appliqued a FUNNY BUNNY cartoon character. Josh examines the label stitched into the collar. It read PROUDLY MADE IN USA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. His light hits a group of quivering, skeletal CHINESE IMMIGRANTS, standing in a tight group against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the outside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look real sick, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying boxes full of terrarium material, Susan and Siri ride an antiquated cage-steel elevator.  No floor buttons just an old-fashioned hand-activated lever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as long as they're ready for the opening I don't care, just tell them that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on it.  Don't worry. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Susan...I don't mean to pry, but... I kinda overheard you and Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles ironically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your step, Siri.  Your grant could be on the line here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just...well, I had this cousin in Delhi.  She was having problems, too. She, ah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She used a baster. Susan looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a big one.  I mean, it was like a turkey baster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. She tries to stop the elevator at the fourth floor, but it rises just a little too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, darlin'... Susan has to jimmy the lever till the elevator falls level to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kept it under her bed. Thing is, it kinda worked.  I mean, she had to hide it from her husband, but... A pair of young boys, RICKY and DAVIS, sit on the floor outside Susan's lab door.  A crumpled paper bag and a sho box sit beside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right... They been here since noon. I told them you're real busy. Susan smiles at the boys, who stand when they see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the bug lady, right? Siri chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Ricky raises and shakes the paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here to deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUNLIGHT slants in to illuminate an incredible array of l and mounted dead INSECTS, trapped in turn-of-the-century glass fronted cabinets. Davis puts his nose up against on fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metaxonycha Godmani, Trigonopelastes Delta.  Field Butterflies.  Have you been upstate? She examines the boys' findings, mostly rag-tag specimens of battered butterflies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avenue B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they got lost in this city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you wanna buy em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's extra wings in the bag. Siri lingers in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys have done a nice job.  How bout five dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismayed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ricky)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show her the weirdbug. He indicates the shoebox-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cost a dollar just to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great bug.  We kinda broke it a little... Siri impatiently points at the wall clock-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas, I'll tell you what...ten dollars for everything.  Plus a killing jar, some tweezers and mounts so the next bunch you catch will be in better shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crazy! That's the best!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bug's almost dead anyway. Susan holds out two five dollar bills.  The boys can't resist.  Davis grabs the money-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, lady. Ricky gives a last possessive look to the shoe box, then follows Davis out. Siri crosses to the window and wrestles to close it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten dollars? Susan places all the kid's items -including the shoebox- a wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alphabet City kids- there's much worse things they could be selling. Siri hits the window frame with a paperweight, gets it ha way down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate this fucking window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE TO a nearby alley. A GAUNT MAN IN AN OVERCOAT stands in the shadows, looking at Siri working on the window. As a streetlamp lights up, he backs up into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Religious slogans and posters are hung everywhere in what used to be the lobby of a men's hotel.  A hand-lettered s

dialogues.speaker: "NO LIQUOR, NO DRUGS, NO PROFANITY"
dialogues.text: PARAMEDICS are leading a number of ill CHINESE IMMIGRANTS from the cellar door seen earlier.  Many are brought out STRETCHERS. DOH staff put tags on their wrists. Peter examines a PALE OLD MAN on a stretcher while simultaneously talking to Josh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Josh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's plenty of systemic infection already, so as soon as we get a preliminary reading, start them on anti-biotics. You saw this? Peter flicks on his penlight, examines the Old Man's eyes One of them is completely bloodshot. Then he shows Josh the gums. They're bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Internal hemorrage. 2 our of 5 have it.  No definite signs of TB, but we'll quarantine them a week just to make sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immigration's gonna love you for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them to send flowers to the usual address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter pushes back a sheet hung across a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BASEMENT SHOWERS
dialogues.text: A tiled nightmare. Concentration camp-cozy. A pile of old rusting sewing machines clutter the floor, spilling oxide to a central grate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two shifts, people rotating from bed to work.  One toilet. We're in Wal-Mart hell, here. Josh swats a fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they get the sleazebag who owns this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triad, Chinese Mafia. They bring people from Yunan. Slave labor... (eyes his notebook)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Harry Wong, a preacher had the flophouse fronting for them. No sign of him. An overhead door is opened. Daylight streams in. Peter sp YANG, an Asian cop, talking to a CHINESE WOMAN lying on a stretcher which hasn't been moved yet.  She is hollow-eye near death.  Her hand weakly hangs on to the cop as if fo dear life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her she's going to be alright. We'll take care of her. Peter kneels next to her, looking at her and nodding whil Yang translates. The woman mutters again, tears of fear i her eyes.  Yang shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's delirious.  Keeps saying the "Dark Angels" are coming for her. She says they took some of her people away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark Angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably a gang.  Chinese people, man. They come up with some wacky stuff. They pull the stretcher out through the open overhead doo and into an

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY
dialogues.text: The stretcher is rolled into a waiting vehicle, its light flashing. Unseen by them, on a brick wall, nearly buried graffiti, is a crude DRAWING. It is of the same, odd figure Peter saw drawn earlier.  T OVERCOAT MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Siri, both wearing Walkman headsets, deftly mou BUTTERFLIES and other INSECTS onto display boards for the exhibit. Rain is blowing in through the half-open window. Their movements are precise and lyrical, the colors and designs of the insects are beautiful. We understand how you can get lost in this world.  Susan works steadily, a partially-eaten PAY-DAY BAR and the wrappers of several others are evidence of her dinner. A PAGER goes off in Susan's lab coat. She takes off her headset; CLASSICAL MUSIC leaks from her headphones. On the PAGER's LCD screen the message reads: LATE TONIGHT. PETE. Susan puts the pager down. Goes to close the window. There is a loud, angry BUZZING sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siri? (louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siri?! Siri pulls her headset off; HEAVY METAL MUSIC leaks from headphones. The BUZZING sound again. We PAN across the various bugs a mounting implements till we come to rest... ...on the SHOEBOX the boys gave Susan. Something rattles wildly inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the fuck? Susan crosses to the trash bin, picks the box out. It vibrates on her hand, then becomes quiet, something moves inside. She slowly opens the lid. The bottom of the box is littered with two inches of shre newspaper. Crumbs of bread and some rice-krispies can be spotted here and there: a kid's idea of a comfy critter's nest. She moves her free hand closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Siri)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you...? Suddenly and INSECT big as her hand springs out of the shredded paper nest and tries to grab on to her! Minute pieces of paper fly through the air!! Susan slaps the lid back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a scared whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you...help me...?

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Siri comes over as Susan grabs steel tongs and a cork dissecting board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna pull it out and I want you to pin it down, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.  Are you ready? Siri nods, pins in hand.  Susan opens the lid and grabs t nymph with the tongs.  The creature goes berserk, flailin its spindly limbs, BUZZING and CROAKING, a milky substanc FOAMING out of its body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God... Susan deposits the insect onto the corkboard. Siri tries to get a hold of it; but it twists out of the tongs and wraps its coarse legs around her hand!! A spide trapping a sparrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!! Get it!  Get it! SNAP!  It bites her hand between index and forefinger. Susan pins the insect into the corkboard. It spins furiou like a crazy LP record. Susan gets a grip on it again with the tongs.  Siri uses pins to secure it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Noticing Siri's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It bit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: leans to get a closer look at the NYMPH: Deep dark brown, flat as a pancake, one rear leg broken, lower tail smashe It squirms helplessly now, looking pitiful under the hars overhead light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This wing configuration. I've never...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at her injury)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck! It broke the skin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're not fully developed.  This thing's not even an adult. The nymph continues to HISS and FOAM, struggling against steel pins. Susan looks closely at the insect's belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Susan gestures to look.  Siri stares down at

dialogues.speaker: THE NYMPH'S TORSO
dialogues.text: where a SET OF VALVES on its underside click in and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's breathing.

dialogues.speaker: SIRI
dialogues.text: shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible.  Insects don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (Picks up a SCALPEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me get a sample. Susan touches her scalpel to the nymph's leg. The nymph CLICKS nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, big guy, hold on... She traps the nymph down and CUTS THE LEG OFF. A painful, agonized BUZZ echoes around the room.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: Susan attaches the insect's leg to a samll holder. It is frozen in a swirl of dry ice. The brittle leg is then mounted in a LASER MICROTOME. Bit bit, the machine executes MICROSCOPIC WAFER CUTS. Siri is making slides out of each section. A series of MICROPHOTOGRAPHIC IMAGES flash onto the scree In the background we hear the high-pitched BUZZ- We see the lights from the mounting room through a glass brick wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the nymph slowly squirming in the FG, then RACK FO to the rain-spattered WINDOW. Suddenly the OVERCOAT MAN is standing on the windowsill! The window is lifted effortlesly from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: prepares a blue solution and places two drops on each sme slide. Reflected in the glass brick behind her we see the man mo across the room.

dialogues.speaker: THE OVERCOAT MAN
dialogues.text: seen only through rippled glass and reflections, moves through the lab. His body STEAMS lightly from the rain. His movements are quirky, spastic. The man observes the imprisoned insects with curiosity. He comes to the nymph, pinned and mutilated on the workta The nymph CLICKS and CHITTERS excitedly, as if communicat with the man. He looks up at the worklight.  It seems to bother him. WHUMP!!! In a blur of motion, he SMASHES the light bulb.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: watches the smear slide.  The blue droplets begin to CHAN COLOR once in contact with the leg section...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on a second... ...slowly turning a deep green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Then, THREE LARGE BEETLES fly into the room. Siri looks at Susan. Susan gets up, hesitant, signals for Siri to stay. We FOLLOW Susan into the mounting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks in, barely able to see her hand in front of her face. The window facing the street is wide open, rain blowing i Something CRUNCHES under her feet.  She bends down, looks She's stepped on the broken glass of the lightbulb. The floor is alive with various INSECTS -- crawling, hopp flying away from their displays, which have been opened. The nymph is gone from the board! She looks under the work table the nymph was on. We LOWER as we TRACK BACK with her.  Something is folded in the corner of the ceiling behind her, camouflaged in t shadows, clinging impossibly to the wall. THE OVERCOAT MAN. He lowers himself with silent grace. Susan whirls.

dialogues.speaker: WHOOSH
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan? Susan GASPS, startled.  We SHIFT to see Siri at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last DOH van takes off under the heavy rain. Across the street, Chuy looks down from his apartment win

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuy sits at the window, twisting wire into a human-like figure.  MOVING past him, we see a group of other WIRE FIGURES on the table, backs of chairs, lamps, everywhere. Manny sits at the kitchen table. He IGNITES a can of shoe polish with a match, then lights a cigarette off the flam He puts the cigarette in his mouth and proceeds to polish pair of shoes. A SILLY SHOW plays over the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too little, not too much. You rub it in, around and around like this. Let the leather take it. Manny leans tiredly against the table. He looks fatigued and in pain. He takes a small pill and places it under his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watching? You should learn to work the shoes. You're good with your hands... Manny shoots a glance over to his grandson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuy...you gonna get all wet. Chuy doesn't pay attention, just stares out at the street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you look at the story book I got you? Manny lifts a brightly colored CHILDREN'S BOOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Animal Friends.  Can you say that, Chico?  "Friends"? Nothing from Chuy.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: The building across the street. Yellow DOH tape at the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend is the one you can trust.  When you are with a friend, no matter where in the world, you are at home. A FIGURE moves out of the shadows and totters in the rain toward the entrance.  It is the OVERCOAT MAN, barely visi in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this city. A friend is a hard thing to find...

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: His face shows a bit of animation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny Shoes... Manny looks up from the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alli.  Mr. Funny Shoes. Manny comes over, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure has disappeared into the dark front of the boarded-up building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is there. Is empty. Chuy doesn't respond.  Manny turns the boy's face to his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuy, listen to me.  They have Jesus on the cross, but that is not a holy place. You understand? Chuy looks at him blankly.  Manny sighs; he knows he does

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Nino.  God only knows what goes on in your head, eh? He pats the boy on the head, then goes back to work. Chuy turns back to stare at the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Funny Shoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The D.O.H. Van pulls up in front of a modest Pre-war building. Josh and Peter climb out. Peter is reviewing a roster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, what was Immigration's countdown? Josh hands Peter a plastic bag with his sweat clothes and running shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-three workers. Peter hands him the roster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are thirty five listed in the reverend Wong's roster...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Peter walks up the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what that woman said, about people being taken? Check with the copsin the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters the apartment, which has long since been remodeled with a nicer couch and a bigger TV with slightl better reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sus? No answer.  He notices the dining room table is filled wi yellowed FILES, all marked JUDAS TRADITOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks around once again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter comes in to find Susan sitting in a chair before a dryer, quietly watching laundry whirl within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Regarding the laundry.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought it was my week for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed to think. It was either this or the weather channel. Peter walks over, kisses her.  He notices an open book of INSECT MORPHOLOGY on her lap. There's a FULL COLOR PHOTOGRAPH of an OOTHECA -- an insect eggcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter folds laundry into his/her piles.  Susan paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This thing was the size of my fist, Peter!! That's off the charts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So you lost a great specimen-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you get it? It's more than that. Peter takes a bedsheet. Susan helps him fold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why insects don't grow larger? Because they don't have a complex respiratory system. What I saw did. It had lungs. Peter walks backward with his end of the sheet.  The two begin to fold it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evolution doesn't work that fast. Something pushed that thing to take the leap. We need to find another specimen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? As they fold the sheet, they move closer together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did a PH test on its tarsal pads. The folding of the sheet has brought them almost face to face. Susan finishes folding herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only two species who match the enzymes I found.  One's a leaf-cutter ant in the Amazon... She has his full attention now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other we released here two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TAXI CAB makes a U turn and cruises on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan ignores the yakking Armenian DRIVER as she scans the buildings and empty lots-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avenue B... again! Maybe you got wrong letter, uh? The cabbie looks up at a Manhattan street map glued over his head on the roof of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going. We'll tell you when to stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they lied to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if they did... that's all we have, isn't it? The cab cruises past the tenement buildings, nondescript stores, junked cars and rubble-strewn lots. It stops before a traffic light. A LEERING HOMELESS GUY with a greasy rag and greasier cleaning solution approaches the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... Oh, shit. Get away, you Turk! The Homeless guy begins wiping/smudging the windshield with his dirty rag. The driver sends him away. The light turns green.  The Driver accelerates, turning on the windshield wipers to expunge the smears left by the guy. Susan sees something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...? Susan motions excitedly.  The Driver pulls over. Susan gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan rushes over, removes something from the windshield wiper. A BUTTERFLY, its wing pinned under the rubber flapper. She holds it in her palm, then looks up at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metaxonycha Godmani.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Susan looks around.  Just ahead is an empty LOT surrounde a wooden fence plastered with flyers for rock bands and performance artists. An identical BUTTERFLY perches on the edge of a board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Peter walk through waist-high GRASS of a small urban wilderness.  Dozens of BUTTERFLIES flutter around t from the weeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want your money back, forget it! Peter and Susan look up.  The voice comes from a RAMSHACK CLUBHOUSE, built of wood scraps and cardboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We already spent it! Susan walks forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here to deal. Long beat.  The door to the clubhouse swings open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLUR of subway cars goes by with an ear-pulverizing SOU At the end of the platform, Davis untwists a wire around busted lock of a locker room door. Peter paces nervously nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, let me... He starts on it himself. Meanwhile, Ricky stares at a PHOTOGRAPH Susan has given to him:  a ribbed, tortoise- brown colored EGGCASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you didn't see one of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An "Ootheca". An eggcase. It probably had more, uh "weirdbugs" inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. I see one of those, I'd puke. Davis opens the door with a CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, abandoned LOCKER ROOM once used for transit worke Susan and Peter walk in with the boys, nervous in the off limits area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in that corner over there. Davis points to a bank of dented metal LOCKERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucker was fast, man. (Picks up a pipe.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to take it out with one a these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, guys.  We'll take it from here. Peter hands Ricky some money. The boy looksdown at it slyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it ten an' we won't tell the cops you're here. Peter regards the little scam artist dryly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's keep it at five and I won't condemn your clubhouse. Peter hands him a couple of dollars more. The two boys take off. Peter removes a PENLIGHT from his pocket. Dust covers everything. A forest of COPPER TUBING and PIP where the sinks used to be.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: inspects the floor. It's littered with cheap objects: chipped combs, used rubbers, soggy newspapers, smeared heroin syringes. Something shiny catches his eye. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, a broken tooth... Something rustles nearby. He notices an old, rotting poster on the back wall.  It seems ODDLY TEXTURED somehow.  He walks toward it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: kneeling, pushes aside a dented trash bin. Behind it, the is a cabinet with rusty sliding doors. A SUBWAY TRAIN RUMBLES by outside, the sound echoes off the tile walls. Susan forces the door back. She peeks through the opening Her face stares back at her from a dirty pocket mirror. She starts pulling something out.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: at the oddly texture wall.  He shines the penlight at it. ...and is met with a FLUTTER OF WINGS.  MOTHS, perfectly camouflaged against the poster on the wall, whiz past him Peter recoils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? He nods.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: turns back to her locker.  She withdraws a cheap PLASTIC NECKLACE from it.  As she removes it, it breaks.  A coulp beads fall away... ...rolls under the locker... ...and BOUNCE -- once, twice, thrice -- each time going deeper till they comes to a stop. Susan peers where the beads fell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something under here. Peter comes over, kneels by her. Susan takes a handful of beads and throws them at the base of the locker. CAMERA TRACKS to follow one of them. It rolls all the way under. A moment later, from some interior space, the sound of it BOUNCING on cement. He shines his light inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very dark. A highlight glints off a shell-like surface. The light barely touches it. THE WHOLE SURFACE BACKS AWAY. Peter drops the penlight.  It gets stuck in a jutting pie of concrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Peter tries to get his hand in

dialogues.speaker: DEEPER
dialogues.text: But he cannot reach the light. It is literally inches fro his fingers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me try.  My hands are smaller. She kneels and goes for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand reaches for the penlight. She barely touches it.  The penlight spins around.  Its l now illuminates... THE FACE OF A MAN.  Unseen by Susan.  Terrifying in its d like simplicity.  In the darkness, its features seem indiscernable, inert, almost frozen in a perfectly symmetrical pattern. It regards the spiderlike movement of Susan's fingers.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN'S
dialogues.text: face squinches with the effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, just leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Susan's hand moves closer, the strange Face begins to TREMBLE. A CLICKING SOUND. Susan's hand is almost there.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: reaches further. And suddenly A BEAM OF LIGHT cuts through the darkness. Their vision resolves. The figures of two MTA COPS stand before them:  ERNEST, 50, burly and bull-necked; and LEON -- African American, 45, more formidable than fat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wearily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan's hand withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost a token, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHH-SHH-SHH.  A felt rag is expertly being pulled across set of pristine black shoes. REVEAL Leonard sitting like a king in a chair, getting hi shoes shined by Manny.  He leans back laconically while arguing with Peter. Ernest examines the ootheca picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I showed you my badge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you gonna have to show me a lot bigger one you wanna go down there. That's the old maintenance grid, Doc. Swiss cheese: tunnels, tracks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Department of Public Health...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...should know better'n to go sneakin' around my turf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  You want me to call your supervisor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please do.  He's a lonely guy. Uninterested, Leonard looks over to Susan and Chuy.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She leans against the wall, inspects her dirty hand. Erne gives her his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gucci.  Flat pump. She looks down at Chuy, who sits nearby, holding a PAIR O SPOONS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your shoes. She stares down at her shoes.  Gucci flat pumps, all righ Susan smiles. Just then, a SUBWAY TRAIN pulls up.  The doors open, disgorging passengers. Chuy flips into action.  He starts playing his spoons, CLICKING them together, slapping them against his knee. Susan watches in wonder as the boy begins to use the spoo to IMITATE the different rhythmical step patterns of the VARIOUS COMMUTERS: The rolling, comical gait of A FAT MAN the lithe haughty step of A PRIM LADY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughs.  To Chuy.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's wonderful!  What grade are you in? Chuy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No school. Shoes're all Chuy knows about. Ernest discreetly points to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immediately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can imitate anything, you just watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Irritably, to Leonard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you talkin' at me. Leonard hands Manny a $5.00 bill for the shine, gets up a walks past Peter as if he were invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (discreetly, to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there some reward for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that could be arranged. Ernest smiles, pockets the ootheca picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Chrissakes.  You gonna lay a two- bit bureaucratic, territorial number on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna keep up the conversation, you best come back with the proper permits and the right attitude. Leonard saunters away with Ernest in tow. Peter shakes his head angrily.  He takes Susan by the arm heads off in another direction. Chuy, without watching, clicks his spoons to the imitatio their steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Peter walk up the stairs; Peter still fumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give someone a fucking uniform and... Did you hear how he talked to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard how you talked to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so I'm the bad guy now? Susan spares him an ironic look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was just doing his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, then I'm the bad guy. Jesus! At the top of the stairs they're completely engulfed by sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants a permit, I'll get him a permit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train blurs by. A FLASHLIGHT BEAM over dirty gravel.  TILT with the beam see Ernest walking his beat past TRACKS and GIRDERS.  Hul out-of-service SUBWAY CARS surround him. He shines his li on the ootheca picture and then around him at the walls. A SOUND catches his attention.  A RUSTLING. He notices something off to a corner, walks over to it. A SHINY BROWN LUMP in the corner, covered in garbage. He touches the lump with his shoe.  It STIRS slightly. He touches it again... ...and a PAIR OF LEGS suddenly LASH OUT, kicking at him reflexively. Ernest jumps back. Another SET OF LEGS emerges... Oddly enough, Ernest relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chrissakes... He grabs the surface of the lump, and pulls it.  We see t it was just a SHINY BROWN TARP. Underneath, a group of THREE HOMELESS PEOPLE -- emaciated toothless -- sleeping intertwined for warmth. In the dim light, they almost seem like a single organism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, c'mon. The Homeless People stare back at him mutely.  Ernest sta getting annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to stick by the maintenance area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah... It's private property now. Ernest looks at her, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eats down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stickman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long John. The homeless man points.  Ernest turns his light. Another SILHOUETTE of the OVERCOAT MAN drawn on the wall. arrow below it points east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graffiti artist, uh? (To Homeless People)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look guys, just get off my beat, you hear?  Get moving. Ernest hustles them out.  The homeless people glare at hi pick up their things and head into the gloom. Ernest watches them go.  He turns back to the graffiti painting of The Stickman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernest walks deeper into the tunnels. Dusklight slants in weakly from grates above. He stops as a RUMBLE is heard ahead of him  He ducks into recess in the wall.  The RUMBLE grows LOUDER, LOUDER. A SUBWAY TRAIN curves around the bend up ahead, its HEADLIGHTS raking the opposite wall to reveal... A FIGURE crouched over something. We hear CHOMPING and SWALLOWING sounds.

dialogues.speaker: CU ERNEST
dialogues.text: Squinting to see over his flashlight beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy! No answer.  Just the wet sounds of food getting chewed an ingested.  Ernest is revolted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off my track... The crouching figure lifts its head and looks around in a unusually quick BLUR OF MOTION.  It's the OVERCOAT MAN. Another distant RUMBLE. Ernest's clothes flutter in the p of hot wind that signals an approaching train. Ernest pulls a CAN OF MACE from his belt, begins to advan The Overcoat Man stands up. Ernest stops in his tracks. For he sees that the Overcoat Man is holding a large OBJE in his arms. Something wet and shiny with blood. A dead dog. The Overcoat Man drops the animal.  It rolls slowly down chest... ...and is briefly caught BY ANOTHER SET OF ARMS EXTENDING FROM HIS TORSO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus... The Overcoat Man lets the animal fall to the ground.  He begins walking toward Ernest. Ernest backs away. The Overcoat Man LEAPS on him just as the SUBWAY TRAIN RO

dialogues.speaker: PAST
dialogues.text: CRACK! Ernest's body is twisted and crunched by powerful arms. Through the strobing windows we see Ernest enveloped by t dark figure, then raised above, taken away.

dialogues.speaker: TRACK
dialogues.text: The can of mace rolls next to the track as the TRAIN CLEA The track is empty again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN across the banner:  'ARCHITECTS OF NATURE'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXHIBITS under glass set up throughout the room: Insect chambers and vaults of great complexity, etc. An opening night CROWD of affluent MUSEUM PATRONS.  All tuxedoes and painted smiles.  Some peremptorily peruse th displays; most just camp out at the buffet table. Peter enters, dressed in his worksuit.  He scans the room, sees Siri leaning against a wall by the buffet table, drinking an orange juice.  He goes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heya. (Kisses her on the cheek.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the boss? Siri gestures to the far end of the room.  Susan stands alone, sipping a chardonnay by an ANT MOUND exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ant mound. Peter notices Siri seems unusually weary. She covers one of her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a headache.  We were sandblasting Trump Tower here since four this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should sit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Go talk to Susan.  She could use a good word right now. She nods for him to go ahead.  Peter leaves. Siri closes her eyes.  She rubs the bandage around the insect bite on her hand.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: approaches Susan.  She's staring through thr glass panes of the exhibit at the crowd of patrons.  In the refraction, their black tuxedoes and evening gowns seem to blend into one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No such thing, baby. She looks over at the crowd congregated around the buffet table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get the feeling they came more for the potroast than the apterids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck 'em.  They don't know what they're missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Distantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Peter looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Susan sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...nothing that a little menopausal's pee daikiri couldn't cure. Least that's what I thought. Peter looks at her, notices that one of her hands is on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely moved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, you were-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just late. Susan nods.  Peter takes her hand. They sit by the ant mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ironic, don't you think?  These guys can hatch hundreds of offspring in a single clutch of eggs, right? And here we are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, we're not b-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan? Susan looks up to see Siri standing on the other side of the glass case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Weakly.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I think...I need... One of her eyes is completely bloodshot. Her mouth is bleeding. She puts her hand on the case to steady herself. Her fingers leave a STREAK OF BLOOD on the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siri... Siri collapses.  The exhibit tips over. Peter pulls Susan out of the way just as the exhibit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siri! The room erupts into COMMOTION. Susan and Peter run to Siri, who lies unconscious on the floor. Peter gently turns her over. Siri's BLEEDING from the corner of her mouth.  Just like the Chinese workers in the sweatshop. Tuxedoed people encircle her next to the insect mounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ambulance races down the avenue toward a distant hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siri is rushed on a gurney toward the Emergency Room. Peter and Susan walk next to it talking to DR. CHRIS RAYMOND, a 35-year old ER physician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I think it's some kind of systemic infection, Chris.  I saw a few cases like it yesterday. A sweatshop in Canal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, look.  You better come in with me.  Help me through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond, Peter, and several other ER STAFF work on Siri, now lying on an operating table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All hands on deck, Pete. Remember the dril?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll come back to me. RAYMOND inspects Siri's wounded hand.  The bandage has been removed.  The bite-wound is infected and suppurating.  A large red circular RASH around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a Lyme disease rash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not consistent with the internal bleeding. Any idea what bit her? Peter shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're gonna need to have that specimen here. An ASSISTANT finishes inserting a catheter down her throat. Blood and fluid leak up through the clear tube. ABOVE THE OPERATING THEATER. Staring down through the circular glass deck, Susan silently observes the procedures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salmon-colored LIGHT slants in from sodium vapor streetli PAN through the shadowy room, past Manny's sleeping form Chuy, asleep under a tent made of an old Star Wars blanke A RHYTHMICAL CLICKING SOUND is heard from outside. Chuy pops his head out from under the blanket, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing only his pajama bottoms, Chuy steps out on the fi escape with his spoons in hand. The CLICKING RESUMES from the building across the street.

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEAD VIEW
dialogues.text: The barefoot little boy crosses the street, steps through center of the huge PAINT STAIN on the sidewalk. The CLICKING sound comes again.

dialogues.speaker: STREET LEVEL
dialogues.text: The CLICKING comes again from inside the flophouse.  It continues a little bit, then stops. Chuy CLICKS his spoons together, mimicking the sound. Beat.  A CLICKING from within again; almost an answer. Chuy ducks under the yellow DOH tape, walks toward the fr of the building. He comes to the boarded entrance.  There is a hole, narro and low in the doorway. Chuy squats, begins to wriggle through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuy steps into the lobby. The CLICKING comes again, from further inside. Chuy moves to find it.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL
dialogues.text: Bits of STREETLIGHT slant in.  Chuy walks slowly, listeni He steps into the SHADOW of a LOOMING FIGURE.  He turns..

dialogues.speaker: CRUCIFIX
dialogues.text: We start on bleeding, nail-pierced feet, then TILT up the twisted body to the face of Jesus, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: CHUY
dialogues.text: stares without emotion at the plaster figure. MOVEMENT to his side.  He turns again. A dimly-lit FIGURE stands before him. Shapes fold and regroup in the darkness, resolving into t tall figure of the OVERCOAT MAN. The Man begins to emit the CLICKING NOISE from under his chin, his whole head VIBRATING. Chuy smiles.  He has a beautiful smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Funny Shoes. He plays his spoons, imitating the sound the figure made. He is answered...but this time, it's from the other side the room. We PAN as he turns. ANOTHER OVERCOAT MAN appears in the shadows. Chuy GIGGLES, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you don't even know what you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that thing was big as your hand.  I don't think I'm going to miss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why take the chance?  Just let me go down there with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Susan glares at him.  Peter sits down by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, listen to me:  you handled that insect almost as much as Siri...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't bite me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  But if it was carrying something...there's a chance you could have been exposed. Susan is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is going to run some blood tests on you.  I want you to stay here till he's absolutely sure you're clean.  Okay? Then you'll call me... You'll catch up with us... Susan looks up at him. Finally, she nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be all right, Sus.  I promise. He leans over, kisses her gently.  But Susan seems hardly reassured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blue hours before dawn. Laconic movement outside.  Ne York dragging itself out of bed. We FIND Manny fixing some melted cheese sandwiches on a h plate. He addresses Chuy's tented bed behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father saw me stay in bed, he'd go get a pitcher. Cold water, whoosh, I tell you that's some alarm clock, brrrrr! Manny cuts the bread in four equal sections and arranges in a star-shaped pattern. A breakfast ritual of some kind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! There you go! The way you like 'em, Chu-chu... (He pours a glass of milk.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're low on milk, you remind Grampa to pick some up tonight, okay? He walks over to Chuy's tent bed. He pulls the sheets asi His grandson is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sewage water BUBBLES in huge tanks. A WORKMAN walks down catwalks above the tank, disengaging larger pieces of debris from the filter areas with grappl hooks.  Shoes, tires, rags... A GRINDING SOUND is heard.  The Workman YELLS out to a CONTROL BOOTH above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold up!  We gotta block on filter D. SOUND of the pump coming to a halt. The Workman walks to the filter area.  He sinks his grapp hook into the polluted waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spooky, silent. The grappling hook moves like a scythe to filter... ...past long, soft filaments of RAGGED TISSUE... ...and connects with a LARGER FORM.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE WATER
dialogues.text: The Workman feels the grappling hook connecting.  He give YANK, hooking whatever it is. He begins pulling it up. A PALE FORM bubbles to the surface. The Workman's face goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... A grating VOICE from the control booth is heard over the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem? It take the Workman a moment to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a baby! The Workman pulls the form (as if that will do any good) toward the edge of the tank. He bends down, and now gets his first good look at it. The Workman SCREAMS. His grappling hook falls from his hand, into the sewage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan watches Siri from behind a pane of glass.  Siri is connected to a respirator, her vital signs monitored by several machines. Raymond approaches Susan, two cups of coffee in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me. He smiles, gives her one of the cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your blood tests were all negative. You checked out. Susan visibly relaxes.  She looks back at the ICU ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Siri?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's stable.  I don't think there's any immediate danger, but we'll have to keep her under observation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's some form of Strickler's, don't you? Beat.  Raymond shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pathology's still working on the tissue samples.  If it is...it must be an errant strain.  Shorter incubation period. (Beat.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sue.  We just don't know yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sink, Susan runs water over her hands, her face, trying to collect herself.  She looks up in the mirror. We see that her eyes are swollen, tear-stained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out of the ladies room, drying her face with a paper towel. SOUNDS of a nearby argument catch her attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...how many times I gotta tell you, man: we can't accept this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what the hell else am I suppose to do with it? Susan heads in the direction of the voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ORDERLY (JEREMY) argues with an EMT.  Their point of contention:  a small FORM lying on a stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it out back and throw it in the friggin' dumpster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless somebody signs for it. Susan walks toward them, catches sight of the tiny form. Her eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. Jeremy notices her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Jeremy...go get Dr. Chris Raymond, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me?  Get Dr. Raymond!

dialogues.speaker: NOW
dialogues.text: Jeremy hesitates.  But if her tone wasn't enough, the stare she gives him certainly is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Jeremy backs away, takes off down the hall. Susan approaches the stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To EMT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you find it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washed up at the filtration plant on Bank street. Some asshole there thought it was a baby. They called us. Susan bends over it.  She covers her mouth and nose at the stench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lobster, right? But it's not.  What lies on the stretcher before them looks more like a demon from a Brueghel painting. A THREE FOOT INSECT.  It's mephitic, pink-white body is rotten, falling apart.  The head's intact, with strange, large jaws thrown wide open. The chitin on one is half gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh deposits a backpack full of equipment on the floor, along with a small acrylic cage. Peter trains his FLASHLI into the bank of lockers. Leonard, weary and pissed, looks at his watch.
